Glendale Unified School District is one of many districts in the state that can’t bring teachers back inside the classrooms for in-person instruction because coronavirus is too widespread in Los Angeles County, but they will welcome about 1,000 young people back to campus in August for day care.

Glendale Unified is disinfecting and preparing 20 elementary schools to provide free day care for about 1,000 children whose parents can’t stay home to help them with online learning when school resumes Aug. 19.

"We have parents who may not speak the language of instruction, parents who are looking for a job because they were unemployed, parents who have multiple kids and they don’t want the older kids to have to take care of the younger ones and interrupt their learning," said school superintendent Vivian Ekchian.

Glendale Unified High Schools Rank Among Nation’s Best by U.S. News and World Report

GLENDALE, CA – All four Glendale Unified comprehensive high schools rank among the nation’s best once again according to the U.S. News & World Report’s 2020 Best High Schools ranking. All four ranked in the top 16% of the more than 24,000 schools considered with Clark Magnet High in the top 2%, Crescenta Valley High School in the top 4%, Hoover High in the top 10%, and Glendale High School in the top 16%.

According to U.S. News & World Report rankings methodology, “the highest-ranked schools are those whose students excelled on state tests and performed beyond expectations; participated in and passed a variety of college-level exams; and graduated in high proportions.”

“Glendale Unified is a dynamic, high performing school district. Our talented teachers, classified staff, and administrators work tirelessly alongside our parents and community to prepare every student for success in college, career, and life,” said Glendale Unified Superintendent Dr. Vivian Ekchian.

post_text: Each week, our Glendale Unified mental health interns provide tips and resources to help our students and families cope with anxiety, manage stress, and stay healthy. This week, intern Natalie leads a 2-minute guided meditation to practice at home. While mindfulness is especially important during this time, incorporating mindfulness in your daily routine during and after COVID-19 could reduce feelings of distress, spark motivation, encourage calmness, promote emotional intelligence, enhance awareness, and more. Mindfulness allows us to create an objective awareness of our emotions, the emotions of others, and of external circumstances. Mindfulness is paying attention to the present moment with openness, curiosity, and without judgment.

The program provides students the opportunity to make up lost instructional time due to absences. Students attend the Saturday program from 8:15-12:15 and participate in fun, engaging lessons across all content areas, designed by participating teachers. Students also receive lunch served by Glendale Unified Nutrition Services.

The Saturday Enrichment Program is funded by the District's ability to recoup average daily attendance funds for the students making up absences. The program is being piloted at Roosevelt this spring with the intention of expanding to additional schools

Schools across the country have been thinking outside of the box for solution to the teen vaping epidemic, and at one Los Angeles-area high school, two juniors

“There’s this vaping problem, which I’m sure that the administrators know of, but nothing’s being done about it,” Krish Shah said.

So Shah and Adam Komjathy created a phone app to try to combat vaping at Crescenta Valley High School in La Crescenta-Montrose.

“There’s almost no way for an administrator to know whether vaping is happening in the bathroom unless they walk in,” Shah said.

The app allows students to anonymously report when they see other students vaping.

On Tuesday, the Board of Education and Student Advisory Council hosted our second Glendale Unified Student Voice Panel. The panel included a diverse group of student representatives from Clark Magnet High School, Crescenta Valley High School, Daily, Glendale High School, and Hoover High Schools. Questions were created by our district Student Advisory Council and focused on four key areas: creating a sense of belonging, boosting school spirit, increasing attendance, and improving communication.

Our students shared their valuable perspectives on the importance of celebrating our diverse cultures and building relationships with fellow students and adults on campus. They also expressed a need for additional mental health support and increased resources to help all students prepare for success in college and career.

We hope you will join us for our final Student Voice Panel of the year on March 24 at Hoover High School.

Today we come together to celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. It is important to learn about the history of Dr. King and the civil rights movement, and equally important that we memorialize Dr. King's mission of equality, kindness, and service.

On Friday, students at John Muir Elementary learned about Dr. King's unwavering fight for equality and honored his legacy by spreading messages of love and kindness on their campus.

Over the coming weeks and throughout African American History Month in February, every Glendale Unified school will participate in school wide service project in recognition of Dr. King's mission of service to the community.

#MLKDay2020
